The Cr(III) precatalysts based on novel N-substituted bis(diphenylphosphine)amine ligands (PNP-type L1-L8) have been confirmed to be successfully synthesized and used to test ethylene tri-/tetramerization properties. Precatalyst 1 with a sec-butyl moiety exhibites remarkable activity of 2257 kg∙g−1∙h−1 with 61.3 % of 1-C8 =. Compared with precatalyst 1, precatalyst 2, with a larger steric hindrance of a sec-butylphenyl moiety at a N-atom, leading to a significant decrease in catalytic activity to 339 kg∙g−1∙h−1. Nevertheless, the selectivity for 1-C8 = increases to 67.9 %. It seems that increasing the spatial volume of the N-alkyl substituents make it more selective for 1-C8 = and lower catalytic activity. Single-crystal analysis shows that complexes 9 and 10 make from ligands 1 and 2 both adopt bidentate (k2-P, P) coordination mode. Simultaneously, the theoretical calculations also suggest that, for precatalyst 1, Path 1 toward tetramerization is thermodynamically more favorable than the other two pathways. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ethylene tetramerization Chromium catalyst N-substituted PNP ligand DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Linear α-olefins (LAO) are usually used as high-quality organic chemical raw materials and chemical intermediates. With the rapid development of the global economy, high value-added 1-hexene and 1-octene are often used in the production of polyolefin materials such as LLDPE (linear low-density polyethylene) and POE (polyolefin elastomers), and the market demand continues to grow [1–6]. High-end polyolefin materials are developing rapidly, and the new energy industry market involving high-end polyolefin materials continues to expand. The huge commercial driving force has promoted the development of LAO production technology. The selective ethylene oligomerization technology can generate 1-C6 = and 1-C8 = with high selectivity, but the catalytic system's catalytic activity, selectivity, and thermal stability still need to be further improved [7,8]. However, the existing catalytic system of ethylene tetramerization produces a significant amount of infusible by-products like polyethylene (PE), which impedes the industrial process of ethylene tetramerization [9–12]. In 2004, researchers from Sasol discovered that bis(diphenylphosphine)amine (PNP) combined with Cr and MAO exhibited excellent catalytic activity for selective ethylene tetramerization. Subsequently, optimizing these structures has aroused great interest in academic research. In recent years, researchers modified the PNP framework and developed other alternatives such as PCP [13], PCCP [14,15], PCSiCP [16], PCNCP [17], PNPN [18], etc. Though these ligands have been found to catalyze tetramerization reactions, however, they are not as effective as PNP in terms of 1-octene selectivity. The excellent performance of PNP-based catalysts for tetramerization could be attributed to the smaller bite angle of PNP and the delocalization of nitrogen lone pairs of electrons between two P-atoms. To study the influence of substituents attached to the N atom of the PNP ligands, Blann et al. [19] introduced an olefin to the central N-atom of the PNP ligand ( Fig. 1, A). They found that when MAO was used as a co-catalyst, PN(olefin)P ligands exhibited lower ethylene tetramerization activity (7.4 kg∙g−1∙h−1) and produced more polymer when the reaction performed at 3.0 MPa ethylene pressure and 65 °C. This low performance for tetramerization of ethylene was attributed to the unsaturated N-moiety which may incorporate into a growing metallacycle and, consequently decrease the concentration of the active catalyst for ethylene oligomerization. Furthermore, they found that when the benzene ring was introduced to the central N of the PNP (Fig. 1, B), the catalytic activity of precatalyst activated by MAO dramatically diminished to 8.6 kg∙g−1∙h−1 at 3.0 MPa and 65 °C [20]. These results indicated that the presence of α-branching at the N-moiety is crucial for the good performance of selective ethylene tetramerization catalysts. In this work, we designed and synthesized novel N-substituted ligands L1-L8 and corresponding Cr(III) precatalyst 1–8 and systematically evaluated their ethylene tri-/tetramerization properties. The findings demonstrate that N-atom substituents can significantly affect the product selectivities and catalytic activities in tri-/tetramerization systems. In addition, the influence of steric bulk on the catalytic performance of N-substituented PNP ligands based systems was theoretically elucidated through DFT calculations. 2 Experimental Methods 2.1 Synthesis of N-substituted PNP ligands L1-L8 The reported literature was followed in the synthesis of the ligands [21], synthetic pathway is illustrated in Scheme 1. To a 20.00 mL CH2Cl2 solution of 1-equivalent of the corresponding amines (10.00 mmol) and a 2.5-equivalent of Et3N (25.0 mmol, 3.47 mL) was slowly added a 10.00 mL CH2Cl2 solution of 2.0-equivalent of chlorodiphenylphosphine (20.00 mmol, 4.41 g) at −20 °C. A continuous stirring of the reaction solution was conducted throughout the night. Vacuum drying the CH2Cl2 solvent after filtering recrystallized the product from n-hexane at −35 °C, resulting in ligands L1-L8 being obtained as white solids in ± 90 % yield. The Supporting Information includes a thorough synthesis process for the N-substituted PNP L1-L8 ligands. 2.2 Synthesis of precatalysts 1-8 To a toluene solution of the corresponding N-substituted PNP ligands (0.42 mmol), CrCl3(THF)3 (0.40 mmol, 0.15 g) was added under stirring. At 80 °C, stir the solution all the time for 12 h. After filtering the reaction solution, the solvent was vacuum-dried. The precipitation procedure was subsequently completed by the addition of n-hexane (15 mL). The product underwent filtration, followed by washing the residue with n-hexane (3 ×10 mL) and vacuum drying, resulting in precatalysts 1–8 as a blue powder in ± 85 % yield. The detailed synthesis procedure of precatalysts 1–8 was illustrated in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Synthesis of Cr(CO)4 complexes 9–10 based on N-substituted PNP L1-L2 ligands Despite numerous attempts, the structural characterisation of the Cr(III)-coordinated precatalysts 1–2 was not feasible as it was difficult to sufficiently generate single crystals fit for XRD investigation. However, the literature that has been previously reported indicates that these catalysts may employ a binuclear complex with a chlorine bridge, [Cr(PNP)Cl2(μ-Cl2)]-group collaboration [22]. Complexes 9 and 10 were formed by treating the L1 and L2 ligands with Cr(CO)6 in a toluene solution at 120 °C, fortunately ( Scheme 3). The gradual migration of n-hexane into the saturated solution of complexes 9 and 10 in CH2Cl2 produced two yellow single crystals appropriate for X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 2). Complexes 9 and 10 display a bidentate binding mechanism for mononuclear k2-P, P, according to the single crystal data. The angle (∠P1-Cr1-P2 = 68.60°) of complex 10 is larger than the angle (∠P1-Cr1-P2 = 67.82°) of complex 9. The angle (∠P1-N1-P2 = 100.15°) of complex 10 is larger than the angle (∠P1-N1-P2 = 99.53°) of complex 9. The detailed synthesis procedure of the preparation of 9–10 complexes is illustrated in the Supporting Information. The CCDC deposition numbers for complexes 9 and 10 are 2412004 and 2412003, and the corresponding crystallographic data are shown in Table 1. 2.4 Ethylene tri-/tetramerization Two reactor varieties were utilized for the ethylene oligomerization process: a glass reactor (1.0 MPa) and a stainless steel autoclave (5.0 MPa). Additionally, both reactors were outfitted with variable-speed magnetic churning blades and internal temperature sensors. Under the N2 atmosphere, add methylcyclohexane, co-catalyst (modified methylaluminoxane, MMAO-3A), and catalyst to the reactor, sequentially. Then, add ethylene to the target pressure and aggressively agitate the reaction mixture. Half an hour later, drop the reactor's temperature to 0 °C, and gradually discharge the pressure via the went. Using GC-FID (Agilent 8890 A) with n-nonane (the internal standard), the liquid fraction was isolated from the solid polymer. The mass of the polymer was determined by filtering and recovering the solid product, followed by vacuum drying and weighing. 3 Result and discussion According to literature, the selectivity of ethylene tetramerization depends critically on steric effects [23,24]. To explore the role of N-substituents in the PNP backbone of bisphosphineamine, the performance of precatalysts 1–8 was evaluated in ethylene tri-/tetramerization. It was discovered that precatalysts 1–8 were active in the ethylene oligomerization system when 1.2 μmol of precatalyst was activated with MMAO-3A at 30 °C and an ethylene pressure of 1.0 MPa ( Table 2). Firstly, we introduced a decyl group at the N atom of the PNP ligand to obtain precatalyst 8, which upon oligomerization may offer a mixed tri-/tetramerization system, exhibiting a catalytic activity 11.8 kg∙g−1∙h−1 and a 58.3 % 1-C8 = selectivity (Table 2, entry 8). Compared with precatalyst 8, precatalyst 7 with 2-ethylbutyl group at N showed a slight increase in catalytic activity (12.5 kg∙g−1∙h−1) and offered 57.7 % selectivity for 1-C8 = (Table 2, entry 7). We further found that precatalyst 7 having β-branch at the chain of the N-moiety exhibited low activity and slightly low 1-C8 = selectivity as compared to precatalyst 6, having 6-methylundecyl moiety at N, with α-branch. To further investigate the role of α-branching, precatalyst 4 was synthesized with a 2-methyloctyl moiety attached at the N atom and its performance was evaluated. It was observed that in comparison to precatalyst 8 having no α-branching, the catalytic activity of precatalyst 4 was significantly improved to 29.7 kg∙g−1∙h−1 and the 1-C8 = selectivity was improved to 67.0 % (Table 2, entry 4). Precatalyst 5 having a bulky group at N-moiety may offer almost similar catalytic activity as precatalyst 4 with reduced 1-C8 = selectivity of 56.8 % (Table 2, entry 5). When precatalyst 6 was contrasted with precatalyst 4, it can be inferred that the long chain within the N-moiety might exert an adverse influence on catalytic behavior (Table 2 , entry 4 vs. 6). Therefore, to reduce the length of the carbon chain, precatalysts 1–3 were designed and prepared. Among them, precatalyst 1 with a sec-butyl substituent, the shortest carbon chain, at N produced 65.3 % selectivity for 1-C8 = and demonstrated the best activity of 82.5 kg∙g−1∙h−1 (Table 2, entry 1). Compared with precatalyst 1, precatalyst 2, with a sec-butylphenyl substituent, dramatically decreases the activity of the catalytic system up to 40.8 kg∙g−1∙h−1 with 1-C6 = selectivity increased slightly (Table 2, entry 2). The excellent performance of precatalyst 1 can be attributed to the stronger electron-donating ability of the methyl group compared to the phenyl group, which significantly increases the electron density of N-atom and thus enhances the electron-donating ability of the ligand, resulting in more electron-rich chromium (Cr) center, which is favorable for the coordination of ethylene and subsequent insertion reactions. As a result, precatalyst 1 exhibited higher catalytic activity than precatalyst 2. In addition, the larger spatial hindrance brought by the phenyl group may limit the accessibility of the ethylene molecules to the Cr active center, thus inhibiting the ring expansion reaction of the Cr cycloheptane intermediate. This spatial restriction makes the reaction more selective for the generation of 1-C6 = [34]. Precatalyst 3 having a 3-methylpentyl substituent at N further reduces the catalytic performance up to 32.7 kg∙g−1∙h−1 without affecting the 1-C8 = selectivity. These results again confirmed that the increasing carbon chain may reduce the catalytic performance of these catalyst systems (Table 2 , entry 1 vs. 3). A similar trend has previously been reported for other PNP-Cr-based systems [19]. Additionally, precatalysts 1–8 have a higher solubility in methylcyclohexane, which may account for their higher catalytic activity [25,26]. The catalyst's efficacy is significantly influenced by reaction conditions, including temperature, catalyst mass, n(Al)/n(Cr) ratio, and ethylene pressure [27,28]. Hence, to optimize catalysts's efficacy of these systems, precatalysts 1 and 2 were assessed for their optimal performance. First of all, precatalysts 1 and 2 were evaluated at varies temperatures and their ethylene oligomerization data were showed in Table 3. Similar to other selective ethylene oligomerization catalysts, the catalytic activity of precatalyst 1 increased significantly from 15 °C to 30 °C, reaching 82.5 kg∙g−1∙h−1 and providing 65.3 % 1-C8 = selectivity (entries 1–2, Table 3). An additional rise in temperature may diminish the catalytic activity and1-C8 = selectivity of the precatalyst 1-based system (entries 3–5, Table 3 ). The minimal catalytic performance and 1-C8 = selectivity occurred at 75 °C. At this temperature, precatalyst 1 may favor 1-C6 = at the expense of 1-C8 = fraction (entries 5, Table 3 ). Similarly, precatalyst 2 exhibited the highest catalytic activity (45.1 kg∙g−1∙h−1) and 1-C8 = selectivity (57.8 %) at 45 °C (entries 8, Table 3), and any further increase in temperature may diminish the catalytic performance and 1-C8 = selectivity (entries 9–10, Table 3). Based on the results, the average kinetic energy of the oligomeric system may rise with a progressive increase in temperature, enhancing the system's catalytic activity [29]. However, too high temperatures may reduce ethylene solubility in the reaction medium. They could also deactivate the catalyst, lowering the activity of the oligomerization system. Notably, precatalysts 1 and 2 can provide high 1-C8 = selectivity at low reaction temperatures, while higher reaction temperatures may be more favorable for forming 1-C6 = fractions. The selective ethylene oligomerization system's catalytic activity and product selectivity are also significantly influenced by the mass of the catalyst utilized in the oligomerization reaction [30]. For precatalysts 1 and 2, the mass of the precatalyst shows a similar trend as exhibited by reaction temperature. Increasing the mass of the catalyst from low to high value may enhance the catalytic performance up to an optimum value and then dramatically reduce it. As demonstrated in Table 4, increasing the mass of precatalyst 1 increased from 0.6 μmol to 1.2 μmol, the oligomerization activity increased accordingly, from 63.3 kg∙g−1∙h−1 to 109.1 kg∙g−1∙h−1; The total selectivity of 1-C6 = +1-C8 = is 82.2 %, mainly dominated by 1-C8 = fraction, with a selectivity of 66.0 % (entries 1–2, Table 4). When the catalyst mass is further increased, the oligomerization activity of the catalytic system significantly decreases (entries 3–5, Table 4 ). Under elevated catalyst loading circumstances, the coordination and insertion of ethylene molecules at the metal active sites is limited by their mass transfer rate, hence impeding the transformation efficiency of active substances and leading to diminished catalyst activity. Precatalyst 2 also followed a similar trend towards catalyst mass loading, as precatalyst 1 does. At a catalyst loading of 1.2 μmol, precatalyst 2 demonstrated the optimal activity (57.9 kg∙g−1∙h−1) and 1-C8 = selectivity (52.7 %) (entry 7, Table 4). An important factor influencing the efficiency of catalytic systems is the n(Al)/n(Cr) ratio [31,32]. Therefore, a detailed study was conducted to investigate the role of cocatalyst/catalyst molar ratios in affecting the efficiency of precatalysts 1 and 2 based systems. Precatalysts 1 and 2 were screened at different Al/Cr molar ratios in Table 5. At 1.2 μmol of catalyst loading, increasing the n(Al)/n(Cr) ratio significantly enhances the catalytic efficiency of precatalysts 1 and 2 up to a certain limit after which any further increase may diminish the catalytic efficiency of the systems. At 300 equivalent of cocatalyst, both the 1 and 2 precatalysts exhibited very low catalytic efficiency (entries 1 and 6, Table 5), however, when the amount of cocatalyst increased up to 1500 equivalent, both precatalysts 1 and 2 offered very high activities of 174.9 kg∙g−1∙h−1 and 117.9 kg∙g−1∙h-1, respectively (entries 4 and 9, Table 5). Further increases in the n(Al)/n(Cr) ratio reduce the catalytic efficiency of these systems. The small amount of cocatalyst may not be enough to activate the precatalysts efficiently, while the very large amount of cocatalyst may decompose the catalysts by over-oxidation [10]. Adjusting the n(Al)/n(Cr) ratios had a considerable impact on the product selectivities of precatalysts 1 and 2. For both precatalysts 1 and 2, low n(Al)/n(Cr) ratios offer high selectivities of 1-C8 = (entries 1–2 and 6, Table 5), while increasing the n(Al)/n(Cr) ratios may favor the formation of 1-C6 = fraction at the cost of 1-C8 = selectivity (entries. 4–5 and 9–10, Table 5). Moreover, elevated n(Al)/n(Cr) ratios facilitate the generation of co-oligomerization C10 + products. The activity and product selectivity of the oligomerization system are significantly impacted by ethylene pressure [24]. Therefore, to investigate the role of ethylene pressure, precatalysts 1 and 2 were tested at high ethylene pressure ( Table 6). At a temperature of 30 °C and an ethylene pressure of 5.0 MPa, precatalysts 1 and 2 exhibited exceptional catalytic performance. They attained 2257.0 kg∙g⁻¹ ∙h⁻¹ and 339.0 kg∙g⁻¹ ∙h⁻¹ , respectively. Moreover, precatalysts 1 and 2 demonstrated significant selectivity for 1-C8 =, with values of 61.9 % and 67.8 %, respectively (entries 2–4, Table 6). This may be attributed to the fact that the large spatial hindrance limits the accessibility of ethylene molecules to the Cr active center, which reduces the rate of the reaction for the migration of ethylene to insert into the metallocyclopentene (Path 1), resulting in a decrease in activity. In addition, the electron-donating capacity of phenyl is lower than that of methyl, resulting in a lower electron cloud density on the N atoms of precatalyst 2, which weakens the metal-ethylene interaction and makes it difficult for the ethylene molecules to coordinate to the metal centers, thus reducing the reactivity. Thus, the lower reaction rate at low catalytic activity allows the intermediates generating 1-C8 = to remain stable for long periods of time, thus improving the selectivity of 1-C8 = [24]. Surprisingly, at high ethylene pressure, both the precatalysts 1 and 2 produce a relatively small amount of polymer product, indicating that higher ethylene pressure helps to suppress the generation of polymerization active species. In addition, as shown in Table S2, we have also compared the performance and selectivity of this work with that of the already reported (Supporting Information) ligand structures for ethylene selective tri-/tetramerization, and found precatalyst 1 exhibit the highest catalytic activity and high 1-C8 = selectivity under similar conditions. (Table S2 in the Supporting Information) To theoretically elucidate the regulatory influence of N-substituented on PNP/Cr catalytic action, precatalyst 1 was studied using DFT calculations [33–36]. According to the mechanism of metallacycle amplification, the whole cycle processes of precatalysts 1 were explored, and all states of transition and intermediates were determined in Fig. 3 . Precatalyst 1 can be transformed into a cation active species ([{PNP}Cr(CH2=CH2)]+) intermediate 6 1 with a sextet spin state under the activation of MMAO-3A. By coordinating with another ethylene, the monoethylene intermediate 6 1 transformed into a diethylene intermediate 6 2, releasing 5.1 kcal/mol of energy. Afterwards, intermediate 6 2 was converted to intermediate 4 2 with a quartet spin state through the spin crossover. Through oxidative coupling, intermediate 4 2 was converted from TS 2,3 to chromacyclopentane intermediate 3 by surmounting 7.4 kcal/mol of energy. After coordinating with three molecules ethylene, intermediate 3 was converted to intermediate 4 by releasing 13.9 kcal/mol of energy to stabilize itself. Subsequently, intermediate 4 faced three possible competing pathways. Path 1 with monoethylene coordinated for tetramerization (the black line), intermediate 4 transformed into TS 4,5 , by surmounting 7.4 kcal/mol of energy and rapidly underwent ring amplification to obtain chromacycloheptane intermediate 5. After coordination and insertion of the fourth ethylene, intermediate 5 formed intermediate 6a with a chromium 7-membered ring. Intermediate 6a can undergo conformational relaxation releasing 3.6 kcal/mol of energy in order to generate a more stable intermediate 6b with the lowing-lying structure of the ethylene-coordinated complex. Intermediate 6b converted to chromacyclononane intermediate 7 via TS 6b,7 after surmounting 8.5 kcal/mol of energy. Intermediate 8, which released 1-C8 =, was formed when intermediate 7 underwent β-H transfer via TS 7,8 after surmounting 6.8 kcal/mol of energy [37]. Path 2 (the blue line) with di-ethylene coordination mode generates 1-C8 = [38]. In terms of path 2, intermediate 4 coordinated with two molecules of ethylene to make intermediate 5’, which gave off 0.6 kcal/mol of energy. Intermediate 5’ surmounts 11.9 kcal/mol of energy and passes by TS 5’,6a to transform intermediate 6a. From then on, the reaction pathway was the same as Path 1. Path 3 (the red line) followed a selective ethylene trimerization pathway. Unlike the previous two pathways, intermediate 5 experienced β-H transfer via TS 5,9 to form intermediate 9 by surmounting 10.0 kcal/mol of energy and produced 1-C6 =. To rationalize the explanation that precatalyst 1 produces more 1-C8 =, the energy barriers of the rate-determining steps (RDS) of Paths 1–3 were compared ( Table 7). Comparing Paths 1 and 3, the difference is mainly in the competitive reaction of the expansion of metallacycloheptane and the β-H elimination. The energy barrier for the metallacycloheptane expansion (6b→TS 6b,7, 8.5 kcal/mol) is lower than that of the metallacycloheptane decomposition (5→TS 5,9, 10.0 kcal/mol), and thus precatalyst 1 favors the generation 1-C8 = over 1-C6 =. In addition, both Paths 1 and 2 tend to ethylene selectively tetrameriaztion, with the main difference being the competitive reaction between single ethylene coordination and double ethylene coordination of the metallacyclopentane. Compared to Path 2, the energy barrier consumed during the formation of the metallacyclopentane single ethylene coordination (6b→TS 6b,7, 8.5 kcal/mol) on Path 1 is lower than the energy barrier of Cr cyclopentane double ethylene coordination (5’→TS 5’,6a, 11.9 kcal/mol). Therefore, Precatalyst 1 tends to use single ethylene coordination to generate 1-C8 =. 4 Conclusions To sum it up, we developed 8 types of novel bis(diphenylphosphine)amine (PNP) ligands. When MMAO-3A as an activator, the combination of these ligands with CrCl3(THF)3 exhibited excellent performance for ethylene tri-/tetramerization. Precatalyst 1 with sec-butyl moiety exhibited remarkable activity of 2257 kg∙g−1∙h−1 and 78.3 % (1-C6 = + 1-C8 =) total product selectivity, with 61.9 % of 1-C8 = product. Compared with precatalyst 1, the catalytic performance of precatalyst 2 with a larger steric hindrance of sec-butylphenyl moiety decreased significantly, exhibiting the catalytic performance of 339 kg∙g−1∙h−1 and 75.3 % combined total product selectivity, with 67.9 % of 1-C8 = product. For precatalyst 1, the high selectivity of 1-C8 = fraction was rationalized by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. From a thermodynamic point of view, our results showed that the monoethylene coordination tetramerization pathway was better than the double ethylene coordination tetramerization pathway and the trimerization pathway. Accordingly, Precatalyst 1 led to a higher 1-octene production, which was in accordance with the experimental findings. coredata.dc:description: The Cr(III) precatalysts based on novel N-substituted bis(diphenylphosphine)amine ligands (PNP-type L1-L8) have been confirmed to be successfully synthesized and used to test ethylene tri-/tetramerization properties. Precatalyst 1 with a sec-butyl moiety exhibites remarkable activity of 2257 kg∙g−1∙h−1 with 61.3 % of 1-C8 =. Compared with precatalyst 1, precatalyst 2, with a larger steric hindrance of a sec-butylphenyl moiety at a N-atom, leading to a significant decrease in catalytic activity to 339 kg∙g−1∙h−1. Nevertheless, the selectivity for 1-C8 = increases to 67.9 %. It seems that increasing the spatial volume of the N-alkyl substituents make it more selective for 1-C8 = and lower catalytic activity. Single-crystal analysis shows that complexes 9 and 10 make from ligands 1 and 2 both adopt bidentate (k2-P, P) coordination mode. Simultaneously, the theoretical calculations also suggest that, for precatalyst 1, Path 1 toward tetramerization is thermodynamically more favorable than the other two pathways.
